text: Then Samson prayed to the Lord, “Sovereign Lord, remember me again. O God, please strengthen me just one more time. With one blow let me pay back the Philistines for the loss of my two eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samson put his hands on the two center pillars that held up the temple. Pushing against them with both hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: he prayed, “Let me die with the Philistines.” And the temple crashed down on the Philistine rulers and all the people. So he killed more people when he died than he had during his entire lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later his brothers and other relatives went down to get his body. They took him back home and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol, where his father, Manoah, was buried. Samson had judged Israel for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man named Micah, who lived in the hill country of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One day he said to his mother, “I heard you place a curse on the person who stole 1,100 pieces of silver from you. Well, I have the money. I was the one who took it.”
“The Lord bless you for admitting it,” his mother replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: He returned the money to her, and she said, “I now dedicate these silver coins to the Lord. In honor of my son, I will have an image carved and an idol cast.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when he returned the money to his mother, she took 200 silver coins and gave them to a silversmith, who made them into an image and an idol. And these were placed in Micah’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah set up a shrine for the idol, and he made a sacred ephod and some household idols. Then he installed one of his sons as his personal priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Israel had no king; all the people did whatever seemed right in their own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day a young Levite, who had been living in Bethlehem in Judah, arrived in that area.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had left Bethlehem in search of another place to live, and as he traveled, he came to the hill country of Ephraim. He happened to stop at Micah’s house as he was traveling through.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where are you from?” Micah asked him.
He replied, “I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am looking for a place to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Stay here with me,” Micah said, “and you can be a father and priest to me. I will give you ten pieces of silver a year, plus a change of clothes and your food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levite agreed to this, and the young man became like one of Micah’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Micah installed the Levite as his personal priest, and he lived in Micah’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I know the Lord will bless me now,” Micah said, “because I have a Levite serving as my priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in those days Israel had no king. And the tribe of Dan was trying to find a place where they could settle, for they had not yet moved into the land assigned to them when the land was divided among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the men of Dan chose from their clans five capable warriors from the towns of Zorah and Eshtaol to scout out a land for them to settle in.
When these warriors arrived in the hill country of Ephraim, they came to Micah’s house and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: While at Micah’s house, they recognized the young Levite’s accent, so they went over and asked him, “Who brought you here, and what are you doing in this place? Why are you here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them about his agreement with Micah and that he had been hired as Micah’s personal priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Ask God whether or not our journey will be successful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go in peace,” the priest replied. “For the Lord is watching over your journey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the five men went on to the town of Laish, where they noticed the people living carefree lives, like the Sidonians; they were peaceful and secure. The people were also wealthy because their land was very fertile. And they lived a great distance from Sidon and had no allies nearby.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men returned to Zorah and Eshtaol, their relatives asked them, “What did you find?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men replied, “Come on, let’s attack them! We have seen the land, and it is very good. What are you waiting for? Don’t hesitate to go and take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you get there, you will find the people living carefree lives. God has given us a spacious and fertile land, lacking in nothing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So 600 men from the tribe of Dan, armed with weapons of war, set out from Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: They camped at a place west of Kiriath-jearim in Judah, which is called Mahaneh-dan to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went on from there into the hill country of Ephraim and came to the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five men who had scouted out the land around Laish explained to the others, “These buildings contain a sacred ephod, as well as some household idols, a carved image, and a cast idol. What do you think you should do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the five men turned off the road and went over to Micah’s house, where the young Levite lived, and greeted him kindly.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the 600 armed warriors from the tribe of Dan stood at the entrance of the gate,
speaker: Narrator

text: the five scouts entered the shrine and removed the carved image, the sacred ephod, the household idols, and the cast idol. Meanwhile, the priest was standing at the gate with the 600 armed warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the priest saw the men carrying all the sacred objects out of Micah’s shrine, he said, “What are you doing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be quiet and come with us,” they said. “Be a father and priest to all of us. Isn’t it better to be a priest for an entire tribe and clan of Israel than for the household of just one man?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young priest was quite happy to go with them, so he took along the sacred ephod, the household idols, and the carved image.
speaker: Narrator

text: They turned and started on their way again, placing their children, livestock, and possessions in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people from the tribe of Dan were quite a distance from Micah’s house, the people who lived near Micah came chasing after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were shouting as they caught up with them. The men of Dan turned around and said to Micah, “What’s the matter? Why have you called these men together and chased after us like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do you mean, ‘What’s the matter?’” Micah replied. “You’ve taken away all the gods I have made, and my priest, and I have nothing left!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Dan said, “Watch what you say! There are some short-tempered men around here who might get angry and kill you and your family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men of Dan continued on their way. When Micah saw that there were too many of them for him to attack, he turned around and went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, with Micah’s idols and his priest, the men of Dan came to the town of Laish, whose people were peaceful and secure. They attacked with swords and burned the town to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There was no one to rescue the people, for they lived a great distance from Sidon and had no allies nearby. This happened in the valley near Beth-rehob.
Then the people of the tribe of Dan rebuilt the town and lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They renamed the town Dan after their ancestor, Israel’s son, but it had originally been called Laish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they set up the carved image, and they appointed Jonathan son of Gershom, son of Moses, as their priest. This family continued as priests for the tribe of Dan until the Exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Micah’s carved image was worshiped by the tribe of Dan as long as the Tabernacle of God remained at Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in those days Israel had no king. There was a man from the tribe of Levi living in a remote area of the hill country of Ephraim. One day he brought home a woman from Bethlehem in Judah to be his concubine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But she became angry with him and returned to her father’s home in Bethlehem.
After about four months,
speaker: Narrator

text: her husband set out for Bethlehem to speak personally to her and persuade her to come back. He took with him a servant and a pair of donkeys. When he arrived at her father’s house, her father saw him and welcomed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father urged him to stay awhile, so he stayed three days, eating, drinking, and sleeping there.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day the man was up early, ready to leave, but the woman’s father said to his son-in-law, “Have something to eat before you go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the two men sat down together and had something to eat and drink. Then the woman’s father said, “Please stay another night and enjoy yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man got up to leave, but his father-in-law kept urging him to stay, so he finally gave in and stayed the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the morning of the fifth day he was up early again, ready to leave, and again the woman’s father said, “Have something to eat; then you can leave later this afternoon.” So they had another day of feasting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, as the man and his concubine and servant were preparing to leave, his father-in-law said, “Look, it’s almost evening. Stay the night and enjoy yourself. Tomorrow you can get up early and be on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But this time the man was determined to leave. So he took his two saddled donkeys and his concubine and headed in the direction of Jebus (that is, Jerusalem).
speaker: Narrator

text: It was late in the day when they neared Jebus, and the man’s servant said to him, “Let’s stop at this Jebusite town and spend the night there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No,” his master said, “we can’t stay in this foreign town where there are no Israelites. Instead, we will go on to Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come on, let’s try to get as far as Gibeah or Ramah, and we’ll spend the night in one of those towns.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went on. The sun was setting as they came to Gibeah, a town in the land of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: so they stopped there to spend the night. They rested in the town square, but no one took them in for the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: That evening an old man came home from his work in the fields. He was from the hill country of Ephraim, but he was living in Gibeah, where the people were from the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw the travelers sitting in the town square, he asked them where they were from and where they were going.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We have been in Bethlehem in Judah,” the man replied. “We are on our way to a remote area in the hill country of Ephraim, which is my home. I traveled to Bethlehem, and now I’m returning home. But no one has taken us in for the night,
speaker: Narrator

text: even though we have everything we need. We have straw and feed for our donkeys and plenty of bread and wine for ourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are welcome to stay with me,” the old man said. “I will give you anything you might need. But whatever you do, don’t spend the night in the square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took them home with him and fed the donkeys. After they washed their feet, they ate and drank together.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were enjoying themselves, a crowd of troublemakers from the town surrounded the house. They began beating at the door and shouting to the old man, “Bring out the man who is staying with you so we can have sex with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The old man stepped outside to talk to them. “No, my brothers, don’t do such an evil thing. For this man is a guest in my house, and such a thing would be shameful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here, take my virgin daughter and this man’s concubine. I will bring them out to you, and you can abuse them and do whatever you like. But don’t do such a shameful thing to this man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they wouldn’t listen to him. So the Levite took hold of his concubine and pushed her out the door. The men of the town abused her all night, taking turns raping her until morning. Finally, at dawn they let her go.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak the woman returned to the house where her husband was staying. She collapsed at the door of the house and lay there until it was light.
speaker: Narrator

text: When her husband opened the door to leave, there lay his concubine with her hands on the threshold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Get up! Let’s go!” But there was no answer. So he put her body on his donkey and took her home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he got home, he took a knife and cut his concubine’s body into twelve pieces. Then he sent one piece to each tribe throughout all the territory of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who saw it said, “Such a horrible crime has not been committed in all the time since Israel left Egypt. Think about it! What are we going to do? Who’s going to speak up?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Israelites were united as one man, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, including those from across the Jordan in the land of Gilead. The entire community assembled in the presence of the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of all the people and all the tribes of Israel—400,000 warriors armed with swords—took their positions in the assembly of the people of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Word soon reached the land of Benjamin that the other tribes had gone up to Mizpah.) The Israelites then asked how this terrible crime had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levite, the husband of the woman who had been murdered, said, “My concubine and I came to spend the night in Gibeah, a town that belongs to the people of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night some of the leading citizens of Gibeah surrounded the house, planning to kill me, and they raped my concubine until she was dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I cut her body into twelve pieces and sent the pieces throughout the territory assigned to Israel, for these men have committed a terrible and shameful crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, all of you—the entire community of Israel—must decide here and now what should be done about this!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people rose to their feet in unison and declared, “None of us will return home! No, not even one of us!
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, this is what we will do to Gibeah; we will draw lots to decide who will attack it.
speaker: Narrator

text: One-tenth of the men from each tribe will be chosen to supply the warriors with food, and the rest of us will take revenge on Gibeah of Benjamin for this shameful thing they have done in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the Israelites were completely united, and they gathered together to attack the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites sent messengers to the tribe of Benjamin, saying, “What a terrible thing has been done among you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give up those evil men, those troublemakers from Gibeah, so we can execute them and purge Israel of this evil.”
But the people of Benjamin would not listen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, they came from their towns and gathered at Gibeah to fight the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all, 26,000 of their warriors armed with swords arrived in Gibeah to join the 700 elite troops who lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among Benjamin’s elite troops, 700 were left-handed, and each of them could sling a rock and hit a target within a hairsbreadth without missing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel had 400,000 experienced soldiers armed with swords, not counting Benjamin’s warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the battle the Israelites went to Bethel and asked God, “Which tribe should go first to attack the people of Benjamin?”
The Lord answered, “Judah is to go first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites left early the next morning and camped near Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they advanced toward Gibeah to attack the men of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Benjamin’s warriors, who were defending the town, came out and killed 22,000 Israelites on the battlefield that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites encouraged each other and took their positions again at the same place they had fought the previous day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they had gone up to Bethel and wept in the presence of the Lord until evening. They had asked the Lord, “Should we fight against our relatives from Benjamin again?”
And the Lord had said, “Go out and fight against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the next day they went out again to fight against the men of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the men of Benjamin killed another 18,000 Israelites, all of whom were experienced with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Israelites went up to Bethel and wept in the presence of the Lord and fasted until evening. They also brought burnt offerings and peace offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites went up seeking direction from the Lord. (In those days the Ark of the Covenant of God was in Bethel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Phinehas son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron was the priest.) The Israelites asked the Lord, “Should we fight against our relatives from Benjamin again, or should we stop?”
The Lord said, “Go! Tomorrow I will hand them over to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites set an ambush all around Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out on the third day and took their positions at the same place as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Benjamin came out to attack, they were drawn away from the town. And as they had done before, they began to kill the Israelites. About thirty Israelites died in the open fields and along the roads, one leading to Bethel and the other leading back to Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the warriors of Benjamin shouted, “We’re defeating them as we did before!” But the Israelites had planned in advance to run away so that the men of Benjamin would chase them along the roads and be drawn away from the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the main group of Israelite warriors reached Baal-tamar, they turned and took up their positions. Meanwhile, the Israelites hiding in ambush to the west of Gibeah jumped up to fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 10,000 elite Israelite troops who advanced against Gibeah. The fighting was so heavy that Benjamin didn’t realize the impending disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord helped Israel defeat Benjamin, and that day the Israelites killed 25,100 of Benjamin’s warriors, all of whom were experienced swordsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the men of Benjamin saw that they were beaten.
The Israelites had retreated from Benjamin’s warriors in order to give those hiding in ambush more room to maneuver against Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those who were hiding rushed in from all sides and killed everyone in the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had arranged to send up a large cloud of smoke from the town as a signal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Israelites saw the smoke, they turned and attacked Benjamin’s warriors.
By that time Benjamin’s warriors had killed about thirty Israelites, and they shouted, “We’re defeating them as we did in the first battle!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the warriors of Benjamin looked behind them and saw the smoke rising into the sky from every part of the town,
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Israel turned and attacked. At this point the men of Benjamin became terrified, because they realized disaster was close at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they turned around and fled before the Israelites toward the wilderness. But they couldn’t escape the battle, and the people who came out of the nearby towns were also killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites surrounded the men of Benjamin and chased them relentlessly, finally overtaking them east of Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day 18,000 of Benjamin’s strongest warriors died in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The survivors fled into the wilderness toward the rock of Rimmon, but Israel killed 5,000 of them along the road. They continued the chase until they had killed another 2,000 near Gidom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that day the tribe of Benjamin lost 25,000 strong warriors armed with swords,
speaker: Narrator

text: leaving only 600 men who escaped to the rock of Rimmon, where they lived for four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites returned and slaughtered every living thing in all the towns—the people, the livestock, and everything they found. They also burned down all the towns they came to.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites had vowed at Mizpah, “We will never give our daughters in marriage to a man from the tribe of Benjamin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people went to Bethel and sat in the presence of God until evening, weeping loudly and bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Lord, God of Israel,” they cried out, “why has this happened in Israel? Now one of our tribes is missing from Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning the people built an altar and presented their burnt offerings and peace offerings on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Who among the tribes of Israel did not join us at Mizpah when we held our assembly in the presence of the Lord?” At that time they had taken a solemn oath in the Lord’s presence, vowing that anyone who refused to come would be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites felt sorry for their brother Benjamin and said, “Today one of the tribes of Israel has been cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: How can we find wives for the few who remain, since we have sworn by the Lord not to give them our daughters in marriage?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they asked, “Who among the tribes of Israel did not join us at Mizpah when we assembled in the presence of the Lord?” And they discovered that no one from Jabesh-gilead had attended the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For after they counted all the people, no one from Jabesh-gilead was present.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the assembly sent 12,000 of their best warriors to Jabesh-gilead with orders to kill everyone there, including women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you are to do,” they said. “Completely destroy all the males and every woman who is not a virgin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the residents of Jabesh-gilead they found 400 young virgins who had never slept with a man, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite assembly sent a peace delegation to the remaining people of Benjamin who were living at the rock of Rimmon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Benjamin returned to their homes, and the 400 women of Jabesh-gilead who had been spared were given to them as wives. But there were not enough women for all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people felt sorry for Benjamin because the Lord had made this gap among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the elders of the assembly asked, “How can we find wives for the few who remain, since the women of the tribe of Benjamin are dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: There must be heirs for the survivors so that an entire tribe of Israel is not wiped out.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we cannot give them our own daughters in marriage because we have sworn with a solemn oath that anyone who does this will fall under God’s curse.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they thought of the annual festival of the Lord held in Shiloh, south of Lebonah and north of Bethel, along the east side of the road that goes from Bethel to Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told the men of Benjamin who still needed wives, “Go and hide in the vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you see the young women of Shiloh come out for their dances, rush out from the vineyards, and each of you can take one of them home to the land of Benjamin to be your wife!
speaker: Narrator

text: And when their fathers and brothers come to us in protest, we will tell them, ‘Please be sympathetic. Let them have your daughters, for we didn’t find wives for all of them when we destroyed Jabesh-gilead. And you are not guilty of breaking the vow since you did not actually give your daughters to them in marriage.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men of Benjamin did as they were told. Each man caught one of the women as she danced in the celebration and carried her off to be his wife. They returned to their own land, and they rebuilt their towns and lived in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel departed by tribes and families, and they returned to their own homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Israel had no king; all the people did whatever seemed right in their own eyes.
speaker: Narrator
